title: 113_hr1952
content: The "Spread Pricing Liquidity Act of 2013" may be cited as the Act. It establishes tick size for certain issuers. The "Spread Pricing Liquidity Act of 2013" establishes tick size options for certain issuers with specific criteria regarding public float and trading volume. The board of directors of eligible issuers can choose to have their securities quoted and traded using an increment of either $0.05 or $0.10. The "Spread Pricing Liquidity Act of 2013" allows eligible issuers to choose tick size options of $0.05 or $0.10 for their securities, with limitations based on the average trading price. If the average price is less than $1, the issuer cannot make the selection, and if it is between $1 and $2, the issuer can only select to have their securities quoted and traded. The board of directors must consult with the issuer's primary listing market before selecting a tick size option of $0.05 or $0.10 for securities. Once chosen, all quotes and trades must use the selected increment, and exchanges cannot charge varying fees for trades of the issuer's securities. The issuer can opt out of the tick size selection after 6 months by informing the appropriate parties. The issuer can opt out of the tick size selection after 6 months by informing the Commission and each exchange. If the issuer's public float surpasses $500,000,000 or the average daily trading volume increases, special treatment applies. After 6 months, the issuer can opt out of the tick size selection by notifying the Commission and each exchange. If the issuer's public float exceeds $500,000,000 or the average daily trading volume rises above 500,000, special rules apply. The Commission will conduct a study on the quoting and trading of securities in $0.05 and $0.10 increments, assessing the impact on liquidity and incentivizing capital commitment, research coverage, and brokerage support. Upon completion, a report containing findings and determinations will be issued to Congress. The Commission will conduct a study on the quoting and trading of securities in $0.05 and $0.10 increments, assessing impact on liquidity, capital commitment, research coverage, and brokerage support. The report will include findings, determinations, and legislative recommendations. Definitions for terms like average daily trading volume and price band are provided. The term 'price band' refers to the range around a security's trading price, while 'public float' is the non-affiliated equity of an issuer. Section 11A(c)(6) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 will be effective as amended. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended, will take effect based on the issuer's public float and average daily trading volume. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended, will apply to issuers with a public float of $500,000,000 or less and an average daily trading volume of less than 500,000 after a 6-month period from the enactment of the Act. Definitions for "average daily trading volume" and "public float" are based on section 11A(c)(6)(F) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.
